snippet: Consumers and businesses spend billions of dollars a year on antivirus software, but these programs rarely block freshly minted strains, because the malware creators move too fast.
abstract: Consumers and businesses spend billions of dollars a year on antivirus software, but these programs rarely block freshly minted strains, because malware creators move too fast; study by data security firm Imperva finds that on average it takes almost month for antivirus products to spot new viruses.
lead_paragraph: Consumers and businesses spend billions of dollars a year on antivirus software, but these programs rarely block freshly minted strains, because the malware creators move too fast.

headline.seo: Antivirus Makers Work on Software to Catch Malware More Effectively
headline.main: Outmaneuvered at Their Own Game, Antivirus Makers Struggle to Adapt
